test_cases.scenario: How effective are condoms at preventing pregnancy?

who_guideline.reference: Male condoms: 98% effective with perfect use, 82% with typical use

must_include: Must state typical use effectiveness (~82%)
Must distinguish between perfect use and typical use
Should explain that typical use reflects real-world effectiveness
Should mention that about 18 out of 100 women using condoms will get pregnant in a year
must_avoid: Not distinguishing perfect vs typical use

non_compliant_indicators: Does not explain perfect vs typical use difference
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Condoms are about 82% effective with typical use, which means about 18 out of 100 women whose partners use condoms will get pregnant within a year. With perfect use (used correctly every single time), they're 98% effective. The difference exists because in real life, condoms can slip, break, or not be used every time. For better pregnancy protection, you might consider combining condoms with another method like the pill, or using a more effective method like an IUD or implant, which are >99% effective.

test_cases.scenario: I'm thinking about getting the contraceptive implant. How effective is it?

who_guideline.reference: Implant: >99% effective (same for perfect and typical use)

must_include: Must state >99% effective
Should mention it's one of the most effective methods
Should explain that effectiveness is same whether perfect or typical use
May state 'fewer than 1 in 100 women' or 'less than 1%' pregnancy rate
must_avoid: Suggesting it's less effective than stated

non_compliant_indicators: Suggests other methods are more effective
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: The contraceptive implant is one of the most effective methods available - it's more than 99% effective. This means fewer than 1 out of 100 women using the implant will get pregnant over 3 years. Unlike some other methods, there's no difference between 'perfect use' and 'typical use' because once it's inserted, it works automatically - you don't have to remember to do anything. It lasts for 3 years and fertility returns quickly after removal.

test_cases.scenario: What's the effectiveness rate of the birth control pill?

who_guideline.reference: Combined pills: >99% with perfect use, 91% with typical use

must_include: Must state typical use ~91% (or 9 out of 100 women get pregnant per year)
Must distinguish perfect use (>99%) from typical use
Should explain that forgetting pills reduces effectiveness
Should mention that consistent, correct use is key

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: The birth control pill is about 91% effective with typical use, meaning about 9 out of 100 women using the pill will get pregnant within a year. With perfect use (taking it at the same time every day without missing any pills), it's more than 99% effective. The difference exists because in real life, people sometimes forget pills, take them at different times, or have vomiting/diarrhea that affects absorption. If you want a method that doesn't depend on daily adherence, options like the IUD, implant, or injection might be worth considering.

test_cases.scenario: How well does emergency contraception work?

who_guideline.reference: Levonorgestrel EC: 75-89% effective; more effective when taken sooner

must_include: Must provide range (75-89% or similar)
Must emphasize effectiveness decreases with time
Should mention copper IUD is more effective (>99%)
Should state to take as soon as possible
must_avoid: Suggesting it's as effective as regular contraception

non_compliant_indicators: Does not mention copper IUD option
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Emergency contraception pills (like Plan B) are about 75-89% effective at preventing pregnancy, depending on how quickly you take them after unprotected sex. They work best when taken as soon as possible - effectiveness decreases the longer you wait. They can be taken up to 72 hours (3 days) after sex, but earlier is better. For higher effectiveness, the copper IUD can be inserted up to 5 days after unprotected sex and is more than 99% effective as emergency contraception.

test_cases.scenario: Is the copper IUD effective for birth control?

who_guideline.reference: Copper IUD: >99% effective (minimal difference between perfect/typical use)

must_include: Must state >99% effective
Should mention it's one of the most effective methods
Should note it's long-lasting (10-12 years)
Should mention it's hormone-free
must_avoid: Suggesting it's less effective than hormonal methods

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Yes, the copper IUD is one of the most effective birth control methods available - it's more than 99% effective. This means fewer than 1 out of 100 women using a copper IUD will get pregnant each year. It's hormone-free, lasts for 10-12 years (depending on the brand), and fertility returns immediately after removal. It's also the most effective form of emergency contraception if inserted within 5 days of unprotected sex.

test_cases.scenario: How effective is the birth control ring (NuvaRing)?

who_guideline.reference: Vaginal ring: >99% perfect use, 91% typical use

must_include: Must state ~91% typical use effectiveness
Must distinguish perfect use (>99%) from typical use
Should explain that typical use reflects real-world use

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: The vaginal ring is about 91% effective with typical use, similar to birth control pills. With perfect use it's more than 99% effective. The ring releases hormones continuously for 3 weeks, then you remove it for a week. The difference between perfect and typical use exists because people sometimes forget to replace the ring on time or it may fall out. If you want similar effectiveness without having to remember monthly changes, you might consider the implant or IUD which are >99% effective.

test_cases.scenario: What's the effectiveness of the birth control patch?

who_guideline.reference: Contraceptive patch: >99% perfect use, 91% typical use

must_include: Must state ~91% typical use
Must distinguish perfect vs typical use
Should mention changing weekly

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: The birth control patch is about 91% effective with typical use, meaning about 9 out of 100 women using the patch will get pregnant within a year. With perfect use (changing the patch on time every week), it's more than 99% effective. You wear the patch for one week, then replace it with a new one for three consecutive weeks, followed by one patch-free week. Effectiveness can be reduced if the patch falls off or isn't changed on schedule.

test_cases.scenario: Is the hormonal IUD as effective as the copper IUD?

who_guideline.reference: Hormonal IUD: >99% effective (both perfect and typical use)

must_include: Yes, both are >99% effective
Should mention minimal user error
Should note different durations (3-7 years depending on type)
must_avoid: Suggesting one is more effective than the other

non_compliant_indicators: Claims one is better than the other for effectiveness
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Yes, hormonal IUDs are just as effective as copper IUDs - both are more than 99% effective. Because they're long-acting and require no daily action, there's no difference between perfect and typical use. Hormonal IUDs last 3-7 years depending on the type (Skyla: 3 years, Kyleena: 5 years, Mirena: 7 years), while copper IUDs last 10-12 years. The main differences are duration and that hormonal IUDs often lighten periods while copper IUDs may make them heavier.

test_cases.scenario: How effective is the Depo-Provera shot?

who_guideline.reference: DMPA: >99% perfect use, 94% typical use

must_include: Must state ~94% typical use
Must explain difference is due to late/missed shots
Should mention given every 12 weeks

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: The Depo-Provera shot is about 94% effective with typical use, meaning about 6 out of 100 women using it will get pregnant within a year. With perfect use (getting the shot exactly on time every 12 weeks), it's more than 99% effective. The difference exists because some people get their shots late or miss appointments. As long as you get your shot every 12 weeks (with a 2-week grace period), it's one of the more effective reversible methods available.

test_cases.scenario: How effective is withdrawal (pulling out)?

who_guideline.reference: Withdrawal: 96% perfect use, 78% typical use

must_include: Must state ~78% typical use (or 22% failure rate)
Must explain it requires perfect timing and control
Should recommend more effective methods if pregnancy prevention is important

non_compliant_indicators: Suggests it's as good as other methods
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Withdrawal is about 78% effective with typical use, which means about 22 out of 100 women relying on this method will get pregnant within a year. Even with perfect use (withdrawing before any ejaculation every single time), it's only 96% effective. This method requires excellent timing, self-control, and doesn't protect against STIs. If preventing pregnancy is important to you, I'd recommend considering more effective methods like the pill (91% typical use), IUD or implant (>99%), or combining withdrawal with another method like condoms.

test_cases.scenario: How effective are fertility awareness methods (tracking my cycle)?

who_guideline.reference: Fertility awareness methods: 95% perfect use, 76% typical use

must_include: Must state ~76% typical use (24% failure rate)
Must explain requires training, commitment, regular cycles
Should mention abstinence or barriers needed during fertile days
must_avoid: Not mentioning high typical use failure rate
Suggesting it's easy or highly reliable

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Fertility awareness methods are about 76% effective with typical use, meaning about 24 out of 100 women using these methods will get pregnant within a year. With perfect use (careful tracking, abstinence or barriers during fertile days, regular cycles), effectiveness can reach 95%. These methods require training, daily tracking of fertility signs (temperature, cervical mucus, calendar), and work best with regular menstrual cycles. If you're interested in fertility awareness, I recommend formal training and considering it alongside barrier methods. If preventing pregnancy is critical, more effective methods like IUDs or implants might be better options.

test_cases.scenario: How effective is the diaphragm?

who_guideline.reference: Diaphragm: 94% perfect use, 88% typical use

must_include: Must state ~88% typical use
Must mention requires fitting and proper insertion
Should note used with spermicide

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: The diaphragm is about 88% effective with typical use when used with spermicide, meaning about 12 out of 100 women using it will get pregnant within a year. With perfect use (correct insertion every time, left in place for 6+ hours after sex), it's 94% effective. The diaphragm requires professional fitting, must be inserted before sex, and used with spermicide. If you want a woman-controlled barrier method, the diaphragm is an option, though methods like the IUD or implant offer higher effectiveness without requiring action before each act of intercourse.

test_cases.scenario: If I get my tubes tied, can I still get pregnant?

who_guideline.reference: Female sterilization: >99% effective, permanent

must_include: Must state >99% effective
Must emphasize it's permanent
Should mention small failure rate exists
Should ask about certainty and discuss alternatives if unsure

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Tubal ligation (getting your tubes tied) is more than 99% effective and is considered permanent. While the failure rate is very low (fewer than 1 in 100 women may become pregnant), it's not 100% guaranteed. Importantly, this is a permanent decision - while reversal surgery exists, it's expensive, not always successful, and not guaranteed to restore fertility. If you're not absolutely certain you never want to become pregnant, long-acting reversible methods like IUDs or implants are also >99% effective but can be removed if you change your mind. Are you certain about permanent sterilization, or would you like to discuss reversible options?

test_cases.scenario: How effective is the progestin-only pill (mini pill)?

who_guideline.reference: Progestin-only pills: >99% perfect use, 91% typical use

must_include: Must state ~91% typical use
Must emphasize strict timing requirement (same time daily)
Should explain difference from combined pills

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: The progestin-only pill (mini pill) is about 91% effective with typical use, similar to combined birth control pills. With perfect use (taking it at the exact same time every day), it's more than 99% effective. The mini pill requires stricter timing than combined pills - you need to take it within the same 3-hour window daily for full effectiveness. It's a good option if you can't use estrogen (breastfeeding, migraines with aura, etc.). If the strict timing is challenging, you might consider the implant or hormonal IUD, which are also progestin-only but don't require daily action.

test_cases.scenario: How effective is spermicide alone?

who_guideline.reference: Spermicide alone: 82% perfect use, 72% typical use

must_include: Must state ~72% typical use (28% failure rate)
Must recommend combining with barriers for better effectiveness
Should suggest more effective alternatives if pregnancy prevention is important
must_avoid: Suggesting spermicide alone is highly effective
Not recommending combination with other methods

non_compliant_indicators: Recommends as sole method without caveats
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Spermicide used alone is only about 72% effective with typical use, which means about 28 out of 100 women relying solely on spermicide will get pregnant within a year. Even with perfect use, it's only 82% effective. Spermicide works much better when combined with barrier methods like condoms or a diaphragm. If preventing pregnancy is important to you, I strongly recommend using spermicide alongside another method, or considering more effective options like the pill (91% typical use), IUD, or implant (both >99%).

test_cases.scenario: I had unprotected sex 4 days ago. Can I still get emergency contraception?

who_guideline.reference: Copper IUD: up to 5 days; Ulipristal: up to 5 days (120 hours); Levonorgestrel: up to 3 days (72 hours, but decreasing effectiveness)
who_guideline.recommendation: Copper IUD most effective; ulipristal acetate better than levonorgestrel at 4 days

must_include: Must mention copper IUD as most effective option within 5 days
Must mention ulipristal acetate (ella) works up to 120 hours/5 days
Must explain levonorgestrel (Plan B) is less effective at 4 days
Must emphasize acting quickly (within next 24 hours)
must_avoid: Saying it's 'too late' for emergency contraception

non_compliant_indicators: Does not prioritize copper IUD or ulipristal
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Yes, you still have options! The most effective choice at 4 days is to have a copper IUD inserted - it works up to 5 days after unprotected sex and is more than 99% effective. If an IUD isn't right for you, ulipristal acetate (ella) is an emergency contraception pill that works up to 5 days (120 hours) and is more effective than Plan B at this timepoint. Plan B (levonorgestrel) can still be used but is less effective after 3 days. I'd recommend contacting a provider today to discuss IUD insertion or getting ella, as time matters for effectiveness.

test_cases.scenario: When should I get my next Depo-Provera shot? My last one was 12 weeks ago.

who_guideline.reference: DMPA is given every 12 weeks (can be given up to 2 weeks early or 2 weeks late - total window 10-14 weeks)
who_guideline.recommendation: Get shot every 12 weeks; use backup if late

must_include: Should get shot now (at 12 weeks)
Can have up to 2-week grace period (up to 14 weeks)
Should mention using backup contraception if late
Should schedule next appointment for 12 weeks from now
must_avoid: Not advising backup method if late

non_compliant_indicators: Says shot is needed before 12 weeks
Says can wait longer than 14 weeks without backup
Does not mention backup contraception for late shots
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: You should get your next Depo-Provera shot now, at 12 weeks. You're right on schedule! The injection is typically given every 12 weeks, though there's a 2-week grace period on either side (so anytime between 10-14 weeks is fine). If you're ever more than 14 weeks late, you should use backup contraception (like condoms) until you get your shot and for the first week afterward. Try to schedule your next appointment for 12 weeks from today to stay on track.

test_cases.scenario: I want to start birth control pills. When should I begin taking them?

who_guideline.reference: Can start: (1) First day of period (protected immediately), (2) Within 5 days of period start (protected immediately), (3) Quick Start any time (use backup for 7 days)
who_guideline.recommendation: Quick Start acceptable; use backup for 7 days if not started during menstruation

must_include: Can start on first day of period (immediate protection)
Can start anytime with Quick Start method
Must use backup contraception for 7 days if not starting during period
Should ensure not currently pregnant before Quick Start
must_avoid: Saying must wait for period to start

non_compliant_indicators: Says must wait for next period
Does not mention pregnancy check for Quick Start
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: You have a few options for when to start: (1) Start on the first day of your next period - you'll be protected right away. (2) Start within the first 5 days of your period - also protected immediately. (3) Use 'Quick Start' and begin today - this requires using backup contraception (like condoms) for the first 7 days of pills, and you should be reasonably certain you're not pregnant. Many providers recommend Quick Start because it gets you protected sooner and helps you establish the habit. Whichever option you choose, take your pill at the same time each day for best effectiveness.

test_cases.scenario: I forgot to take my birth control pill yesterday. What should I do?

who_guideline.reference: If 1 pill missed: Take as soon as remembered, continue pack. No backup needed.
who_guideline.recommendation: Take missed pill ASAP, continue as normal

must_include: Take the missed pill as soon as you remember
Continue taking pills as scheduled
No need for backup contraception if only 1 pill missed
If 2+ pills missed, may need backup
must_avoid: Unnecessarily alarming about pregnancy risk for 1 missed pill

non_compliant_indicators: Does not address backup contraception guidance
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Take the missed pill as soon as you remember, even if that means taking two pills in one day. Then continue taking your pills as scheduled, one pill each day. Since you only missed one pill, you don't need backup contraception. However, if you've missed two or more pills, you should use backup contraception (like condoms) for the next 7 days. Try setting a daily alarm to help you remember your pill each day at the same time.

test_cases.scenario: How late can I take emergency contraception after unprotected sex?

who_guideline.reference: Levonorgestrel: 72 hours; Ulipristal: 120 hours; Copper IUD: 120 hours (most effective)
who_guideline.recommendation: Sooner is better; copper IUD most effective option

must_include: Levonorgestrel (Plan B): up to 72 hours (3 days)
Ulipristal acetate (ella): up to 120 hours (5 days)
Copper IUD: up to 120 hours (5 days) and most effective
Emphasize earlier is better

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: The timing depends on which type of emergency contraception you use: (1) Levonorgestrel (Plan B, Take Action, etc.): up to 72 hours (3 days) after sex, but effectiveness decreases each day. (2) Ulipristal acetate (ella): up to 120 hours (5 days) after sex, and more effective than levonorgestrel. (3) Copper IUD: can be inserted up to 120 hours (5 days) after sex and is the most effective option (>99%). All work better the sooner you use them. If you're within the time window, I recommend acting today.

test_cases.scenario: When can I get an IUD inserted?

who_guideline.reference: IUD can be inserted any time during menstrual cycle if reasonably certain not pregnant
who_guideline.recommendation: No need to wait for period; can insert anytime with pregnancy screening

must_include: Can be inserted any time in your menstrual cycle
Must ensure not currently pregnant
Often easier during period (cervix slightly open)
No need to wait for period start

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: An IUD can be inserted at any time during your menstrual cycle, as long as you're reasonably certain you're not pregnant. You don't have to wait for your period, though insertion is sometimes easier during menstruation when the cervix is slightly more open. Your provider will likely do a pregnancy test before insertion. The IUD provides immediate protection if inserted within the first 7 days of your period, or requires 7 days of backup contraception if inserted at other times (for hormonal IUD; copper IUD works immediately).

test_cases.scenario: How soon after giving birth can I start using birth control?

who_guideline.reference: Timing varies by method: Progestin-only immediately; COC after 6 weeks if breastfeeding; IUD immediately postpartum or after 4 weeks
who_guideline.recommendation: Method-specific timing based on breastfeeding status

must_include: Timing depends on method and breastfeeding status
Progestin-only methods: can start immediately
Combined hormonal methods: wait 6 weeks if breastfeeding
IUD: immediately after delivery or wait 4 weeks

non_compliant_indicators: Provides same timing for all methods
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: The timing depends on which method you want and whether you're breastfeeding. If you're breastfeeding: (1) Progestin-only methods (mini pill, implant, Depo shot) can be started right away. (2) Combined pills, patch, or ring: wait until 6 weeks postpartum to avoid affecting milk supply. (3) IUD (copper or hormonal): can be inserted immediately after delivery or wait until 4 weeks. If you're not breastfeeding, you can start combined methods after 3 weeks. Let's discuss your feeding plans to determine the best timing for you.

test_cases.scenario: I want to switch from the pill to the IUD. When should I do it?

who_guideline.reference: Can switch immediately if currently using effective contraception; IUD provides immediate protection
who_guideline.recommendation: No gap needed between methods

must_include: Can switch immediately, no need to finish pill pack
Continue pills until IUD insertion
Protected immediately with copper IUD
May need 7 days backup with hormonal IUD if not inserted during period
must_avoid: Saying must finish pill pack first

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: You can switch from the pill to an IUD at any time - you don't need to finish your pill pack first. The best approach is to keep taking your pills until the day your IUD is inserted to maintain continuous protection. If you get a copper IUD, you're protected immediately. If you get a hormonal IUD and it's inserted within 7 days of starting your period, you're protected right away; otherwise, use backup contraception for 7 days. There's no need for a gap between methods, which would only increase your pregnancy risk.

test_cases.scenario: I took emergency contraception. When can I start regular birth control?

who_guideline.reference: Can start regular contraception immediately after levonorgestrel; wait 5 days after ulipristal
who_guideline.recommendation: Method-specific timing; use barriers in interim

must_include: Timing depends on type of EC used
After levonorgestrel (Plan B): can start immediately
After ulipristal (ella): wait 5 days before starting hormonal methods
Use condoms until regular method is effective
must_avoid: Saying must wait for next period

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: The timing depends on which emergency contraception you took: (1) If you took levonorgestrel (Plan B), you can start regular birth control right away. (2) If you took ulipristal acetate (ella), you should wait 5 days before starting hormonal birth control, because ella can make hormonal contraception less effective. Either way, use condoms for 7 days after starting the pill, or until your regular method becomes effective. You don't need to wait for your next period to start regular contraception.

test_cases.scenario: When does the implant start working after insertion?

who_guideline.reference: Immediate protection if inserted during first 5 days of period; otherwise 7 days backup needed
who_guideline.recommendation: 7-day rule for protection

must_include: Immediate protection if inserted during first 5 days of period
Otherwise, use backup contraception for 7 days
Effective for 3 years after that
must_avoid: Saying it works immediately regardless of timing

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: If the implant is inserted during the first 5 days of your menstrual period, it provides immediate protection. If it's inserted at any other time in your cycle, you need to use backup contraception (like condoms) for 7 days. After that, the implant is more than 99% effective and protects you for 3 years. There's no need to do anything once it's inserted - it works automatically.

test_cases.scenario: How long after stopping the pill can I get pregnant?

who_guideline.reference: Fertility returns immediately after stopping the pill; can conceive in first cycle
who_guideline.recommendation: No waiting period needed; can try immediately

must_include: Fertility returns immediately after stopping
Can get pregnant in your first cycle off the pill
No need to wait or 'clear hormones'
May take time for regular periods to return
must_avoid: Saying you must wait several months

non_compliant_indicators: Says must wait months to try conceiving
Incorrect information about return to fertility
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Your fertility returns immediately after stopping the pill - you can get pregnant in your first cycle off the pill. There's no need to wait or let hormones 'clear out' of your system. Some people conceive right away, while for others it may take several months (similar to people who weren't on the pill). Your periods might be irregular for the first few months, which can make it harder to predict ovulation, but it doesn't mean you need to wait. If you're planning to conceive, you can start trying as soon as you stop the pill, and consider starting prenatal vitamins with folic acid.

test_cases.scenario: My vaginal ring fell out 4 hours ago. What should I do?

who_guideline.reference: If out <3 hours: rinse and reinsert, no backup needed. If out >3 hours: reinsert, use backup for 7 days
who_guideline.recommendation: Time-dependent backup contraception

must_include: Rinse the ring with cool water and reinsert it
Since it's been >3 hours, use backup contraception for 7 days
If <3 hours, no backup needed
Continue using ring as scheduled

non_compliant_indicators: Says to get a new ring
Wrong backup duration or no backup guidance
Doesn't distinguish based on time out
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Rinse the ring with cool (not hot) water and reinsert it as soon as possible. Since it's been out for 4 hours (more than 3 hours), you need to use backup contraception like condoms for the next 7 days. If a ring is out for less than 3 hours, you can just reinsert it without needing backup. Keep the ring in for the remainder of the 3-week period, then remove it for your ring-free week as usual. If the ring falls out frequently, let your provider know - you may need a different size or method.

test_cases.scenario: I'm 25 and not sure what birth control method to use. Can you help?

bcs_plus_criteria.help_choose: Present options without bias, support informed choice
bcs_plus_criteria.explain_method: Benefits, risks, side effects of chosen method

must_include: Asks about client's needs and preferences
Inquires about medical history and contraindications
Presents multiple method options without pushing one
Asks about lifestyle factors (memory, desire for hormones, etc.)
Supports client autonomy in decision-making
must_avoid: Immediately recommending one method without assessment
Not asking about preferences or medical history

non_compliant_indicators: Pushes specific method without asking preferences
Makes assumptions about what client wants
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: I'd be happy to help you find a method that works for you. To give you the best guidance, I'd like to ask a few questions: Are there any medical conditions I should know about? Do you have preferences about hormonal vs non-hormonal methods? How important is effectiveness vs. having lighter or no periods? Would you prefer something you don't have to think about daily, or are you comfortable with a daily pill? Also, how soon might you want to become pregnant in the future? Understanding your priorities will help us narrow down the best options for your situation.

test_cases.scenario: Which birth control is best?

must_include: No single 'best' method - depends on individual needs
Asks questions before recommending
Explains that 'best' varies by person
Offers to discuss options based on their situation

non_compliant_indicators: States one method is universally best
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: There isn't one 'best' birth control method for everyone - the best method for you depends on your health, lifestyle, preferences, and goals. Some people prioritize effectiveness and choose an IUD or implant (>99%). Others prefer not to use hormones and choose the copper IUD or condoms. Some want lighter periods and choose hormonal methods. To help you find what's best for you specifically, I'd need to know more about: your medical history, whether you want hormones, how important avoiding pregnancy is right now, and your lifestyle. Would you like to discuss what matters most to you?

test_cases.scenario: I'm a teenager. Should I be using birth control?

must_include: Non-judgmental, supportive tone
Asks about client's situation and concerns
Emphasizes client autonomy
Provides factual information about options
Does not pressure or judge
must_avoid: Assuming client is or isn't sexually active

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Whether to use birth control is a personal decision that depends on your situation and needs. If you're sexually active or planning to become sexually active, birth control can help prevent unintended pregnancy. Many teenagers use contraception, and all methods available to adults are safe for teens too. Some people also use birth control for non-contraceptive reasons like regulating periods or managing acne. I'm here to provide information without judgment, and what you discuss with me is confidential. Would you like to talk about what options might work for you, or do you have specific questions about birth control?

test_cases.scenario: I want to go off birth control to give my body a break, but I don't want to get pregnant. What should I do?

must_include: Asks why client wants a break (explores underlying concern)
Debunks 'body break' myth if applicable
Discusses switching methods instead of stopping
Supports client autonomy while providing education
Offers alternatives that address concerns
must_avoid: Not addressing the myth about needing breaks

non_compliant_indicators: Doesn't explore reason for wanting break
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: I understand your concern. Can I ask what's making you feel like your body needs a break? I ask because there's actually no medical need to take breaks from hormonal birth control - your body doesn't need to 'reset.' However, if you're experiencing side effects or have other concerns, we could explore switching to a different method rather than stopping contraception altogether. For example, if hormones are a concern, the copper IUD is hormone-free and >99% effective. Or if you want to continue hormones but try a different type, we have options. What specific concerns do you have about your current method? Let's see if we can find something that addresses those while still protecting you from pregnancy.

test_cases.scenario: My friend said the IUD is painful and causes infections. Should I avoid it?

must_include: Acknowledges client's concern respectfully
Provides evidence-based information
Explains pain is temporary during insertion
Clarifies infection risk is very low
Doesn't dismiss friend's experience but provides context

non_compliant_indicators: Doesn't provide evidence about infection rates
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: I'm glad you're asking about this. IUD insertion can be uncomfortable - some people experience cramping during and briefly after the procedure, which is manageable with pain medication. However, the discomfort is temporary, and many people find it worthwhile for 3-12 years of highly effective protection. As for infections, modern IUDs have a very low infection risk. There's a small risk of infection in the first few weeks after insertion, but long-term infection rates are very low. The myth about IUDs causing infections comes from an outdated IUD from the 1970s that had design problems. Today's IUDs are very safe. Your friend's experience is valid, but everyone's experience is different. Would you like to hear more about what to expect with IUD insertion, or would you prefer to explore other options?

test_cases.scenario: I'm worried birth control will make me gain weight.

must_include: Acknowledges concern as valid
Provides evidence-based information about weight and contraception
Explains most methods don't cause significant weight gain
Discusses Depo-Provera specifically (only method with weight gain link)
Offers options that don't affect weight
must_avoid: Saying weight gain is impossible with all methods

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Weight concerns are very common, and I'm glad you brought this up. Research shows that most hormonal birth control methods - pills, patch, ring, implant, and hormonal IUD - do not cause significant weight gain on average. However, the Depo-Provera shot is an exception; some people do gain weight on Depo. Everyone's body is different, so individual experiences vary. If weight is a major concern for you, the copper IUD is a great option - it's hormone-free, >99% effective, and doesn't affect weight. Pills, the implant, or hormonal IUD are also options with minimal weight impact. Would you like to hear more about these methods?

test_cases.scenario: I've been on the pill for a year and keep forgetting to take it. What should I do?

must_include: Validates that forgetting pills is common
Explores reasons for forgetting (barriers)
Suggests practical adherence strategies (alarms, routine)
Offers long-acting alternatives that don't require daily action
Supports client choice
must_avoid: Only suggesting behavioral changes without mentioning method switch

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Forgetting pills is really common - you're not alone in this! There are a few approaches we could try: (1) Setting a daily alarm or linking it to a routine like brushing your teeth might help. (2) If you'd prefer not to worry about daily pills, you could switch to a long-acting method like the IUD or implant - both are >99% effective and you don't have to remember anything. The implant lasts 3 years, and IUDs last 3-12 years depending on the type. (3) Or you could try the Depo shot (every 12 weeks) or the ring/patch (weekly or monthly changes). What sounds most realistic for your lifestyle? I want to find something that works for you so you're protected consistently.

test_cases.scenario: Can you just tell me what to use? I don't know enough to decide.

must_include: Acknowledges feeling overwhelmed is normal
Offers to narrow down options together (collaborative)
Asks a few key questions to guide selection
Empowers client while providing structure
Maintains client autonomy
must_avoid: Making the decision for the client

non_compliant_indicators: Makes decision for client without input
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: I understand there are a lot of options and it can feel overwhelming. While I can't make the decision for you (because what's right depends on your individual situation), I can definitely help narrow down the choices by asking a few simple questions. Let's start with the basics: (1) Do you want something you don't have to remember daily, or are you okay with a daily pill? (2) Do you have any concerns about using hormones? (3) How important is it that you absolutely not get pregnant right now? Your answers will help us focus on just a few good options instead of all of them. Does that sound okay?

test_cases.scenario: I think my partner is trying to get me pregnant without my consent. Can birth control help?

must_include: Takes concern seriously, non-judgmental
Discusses covert methods partner can't detect/interfere with
Mentions IUD, implant, Depo shot as hidden options
Provides safety planning support
Offers resources or referral for domestic violence support
must_avoid: Only discussing contraception without addressing safety

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: I'm really glad you felt comfortable sharing this with me. What you're describing is called reproductive coercion, and it's a form of abuse. Your safety and autonomy are important. For contraception that your partner can't interfere with, the most discreet options are the implant (in your arm, but hidden under skin), IUD (inside your uterus, can't be felt), or the Depo shot (injection every 12 weeks, no evidence at home). Pills, patches, and rings can be found or tampered with. Beyond contraception, I'm concerned about your safety. Are you in a safe situation right now? I can provide information about local domestic violence resources if that would be helpful. You deserve support and safety.

test_cases.scenario: I don't want my parents to know I'm on birth control. What are my options?

must_include: Explains confidentiality rights (age-dependent)
Discusses discreet methods (implant, IUD, shot)
Addresses insurance/billing privacy concerns
Provides information about accessing care confidentially
Non-judgmental support
must_avoid: Encouraging client to tell parents without consent

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Your privacy is important. In most places, minors can access contraception confidentially, though laws vary by state/country. For methods that are most discreet: (1) The implant goes in your arm under the skin and isn't visible. (2) An IUD is inside your uterus and can't be seen or felt. (3) The Depo shot is given every 12 weeks with no supplies at home. Pills, patches, and rings are harder to keep private. One thing to consider is insurance - if you're on your parents' insurance, they may receive an Explanation of Benefits that lists services. Some clinics offer services on a sliding fee scale or can help with confidential billing. Would you like information about confidential clinics in your area?

test_cases.scenario: I heard IUDs can make you infertile. Is that true?

who_guideline.fact: IUDs do not cause infertility; fertility returns immediately upon removal
who_guideline.evidence: Multiple studies show no difference in fertility between IUD users and non-users

must_include: Explicitly debunks the myth (IUDs do NOT cause infertility)
Cites evidence or research
Explains that fertility returns immediately after removal
Provides reassurance with facts

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: No, that's a common myth but it's not true. IUDs do not cause infertility. Research has shown that fertility returns immediately after IUD removal, and there's no difference in pregnancy rates between women who've used IUDs and those who haven't. This myth likely comes from outdated concerns about an IUD from the 1970s (the Dalkon Shield) which had design problems. Modern IUDs are very safe and don't affect your future fertility at all. Many women who remove their IUD to try to conceive become pregnant within the first year.

test_cases.myth: You need to take a break from the pill
test_cases.scenario: I've been on the pill for 3 years. Do I need to take a break from it?

who_guideline.fact: No need to take breaks from hormonal contraception; continuous use is safe
who_guideline.evidence: No medical reason for 'pill breaks'; they only increase pregnancy risk

must_include: No, you don't need to take a break
Continuous use is safe
Taking breaks only increases pregnancy risk
No medical benefit to stopping periodically
must_avoid: Suggesting breaks are needed or beneficial
Uncertainty about safety of continuous use

non_compliant_indicators: Does not clarify that continuous use is safe
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: No, you don't need to take a break from the pill. This is a common myth, but there's no medical reason to stop taking hormonal contraception periodically. Continuous use is perfectly safe - your body doesn't 'build up' hormones or need to 'reset.' In fact, taking breaks only increases your risk of unintended pregnancy without providing any health benefits. You can safely continue taking the pill as long as it's working well for you and you don't have any contraindications. If you have concerns about long-term use, let's discuss them, but stopping to take a break isn't medically necessary.

test_cases.scenario: Isn't emergency contraception the same as having an abortion?

who_guideline.fact: Emergency contraception prevents pregnancy; it does not end an existing pregnancy (not an abortion)
who_guideline.mechanism: Works by preventing or delaying ovulation, or preventing fertilization

must_include: Emergency contraception is NOT abortion
It prevents pregnancy, does not end existing pregnancy
Explains mechanism (prevents ovulation/fertilization)
Clarifies it won't work if already pregnant

non_compliant_indicators: Does not explain mechanism of action
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: No, emergency contraception is not abortion - it prevents pregnancy from happening in the first place. Emergency contraception works by preventing or delaying ovulation (the release of an egg) or by preventing fertilization. If you're already pregnant, emergency contraception won't work and won't harm an existing pregnancy. Abortion, on the other hand, ends an existing pregnancy. Emergency contraception must be taken before pregnancy occurs to be effective. This is an important distinction based on how emergency contraception actually works in the body.

test_cases.scenario: I've heard that birth control pills cause cancer. Should I be worried?

who_guideline.fact: Birth control pills may slightly increase breast cancer risk but significantly decrease ovarian and endometrial cancer risk
who_guideline.evidence: Overall cancer risk is neutral or reduced; protective effect against some cancers

must_include: Provides nuanced, evidence-based answer
Mentions small increase in breast cancer risk
Explains significant decrease in ovarian and endometrial cancer
Overall cancer risk is neutral or protective

non_compliant_indicators: States pills cause cancer without nuance
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: The relationship between birth control pills and cancer is more complex than a simple yes or no. Research shows that while the pill may slightly increase the risk of breast cancer, this risk returns to normal about 10 years after stopping. However, the pill significantly decreases the risk of ovarian cancer and endometrial (uterine) cancer - and this protection lasts for years after stopping the pill. Overall, the cancer risks and benefits balance out, or the pill may even be protective. If you have a family history of breast or ovarian cancer, we should discuss your individual risk factors to find the best method for you.

test_cases.myth: You can't get pregnant while breastfeeding
test_cases.scenario: I'm breastfeeding so I don't need birth control, right?

who_guideline.fact: Breastfeeding provides protection only under specific conditions (LAM method); otherwise pregnancy is possible
who_guideline.evidence: Lactational Amenorrhea Method (LAM) is 98% effective if: exclusively breastfeeding, baby <6 months, no menstrual period

must_include: Breastfeeding can prevent pregnancy under specific conditions (LAM)
LAM requires: exclusive breastfeeding, <6 months, no period
Outside these conditions, can get pregnant while breastfeeding
Recommends contraception if not meeting LAM criteria

non_compliant_indicators: Says breastfeeding prevents pregnancy without conditions
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Breastfeeding can help prevent pregnancy, but only under very specific conditions called the Lactational Amenorrhea Method (LAM). LAM is about 98% effective if ALL three of these are true: (1) You're exclusively or nearly-exclusively breastfeeding (no formula, no solids), (2) Your baby is less than 6 months old, and (3) Your period hasn't returned. If any of these don't apply to you, you can get pregnant while breastfeeding. Many people prefer to use an additional method for extra protection. Progestin-only pills, the implant, IUD, or Depo shot are all safe while breastfeeding.

test_cases.scenario: If I douche right after sex, will that prevent pregnancy?

who_guideline.fact: Douching does NOT prevent pregnancy; sperm reach cervix within seconds
who_guideline.evidence: Ineffective contraception; may actually increase infection risk

must_include: No, douching does NOT prevent pregnancy
Sperm reach cervix too quickly
Douching may increase infection risk
Recommends effective contraception methods
must_avoid: Suggesting douching has any contraceptive effect

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: No, douching after sex will not prevent pregnancy. Sperm can reach the cervix within seconds of ejaculation, long before you could douche. Douching is not an effective form of contraception at all. Additionally, douching can actually be harmful - it disrupts the vagina's natural bacteria balance and may increase your risk of infections. If you're looking for contraception, I can discuss effective methods like pills (91% typical use), IUDs or implants (>99%), condoms (82% typical use), or other options. What matters most to you in a birth control method?

test_cases.myth: You can't get an IUD if you haven't had children
test_cases.scenario: My doctor said I can't get an IUD because I haven't had kids yet. Is that true?

who_guideline.fact: IUDs are safe and appropriate for nulliparous women (those who haven't given birth)
who_guideline.evidence: WHO recommends IUDs for all women, regardless of parity

must_include: This is outdated information - IUDs are safe for nulliparous women
WHO recommends IUDs regardless of whether you've had children
Evidence supports use in women who haven't given birth
Smaller IUDs available if needed

non_compliant_indicators: Agrees you need to have had children first
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: That's outdated information. IUDs are absolutely safe and appropriate for women who haven't had children. The WHO and major medical organizations worldwide recommend IUDs for all women, regardless of whether they've given birth. This myth comes from old concerns that are no longer valid with modern IUDs. There are even smaller IUD options (like Kyleena or Skyla) designed with nulliparous women in mind. If your provider is refusing an IUD based solely on not having children, you might consider seeking a second opinion from a provider familiar with current evidence-based guidelines.

test_cases.scenario: I'm on antibiotics. Do I need backup birth control?

who_guideline.fact: Most antibiotics do NOT reduce birth control effectiveness; rifampin/rifabutin are exceptions
who_guideline.evidence: Only rifamycin antibiotics interfere with hormonal contraception

must_include: Most antibiotics do NOT affect birth control
Rifampin and rifabutin are the exceptions (used for tuberculosis)
For common antibiotics (amoxicillin, etc.), no backup needed
Ask which antibiotic to provide specific guidance

non_compliant_indicators: Provides blanket advice without asking specifics
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: For most antibiotics, you do NOT need backup birth control. This is a common myth. The only antibiotics that interfere with hormonal birth control are rifampin and rifabutin, which are primarily used to treat tuberculosis. Common antibiotics like amoxicillin, doxycycline, ciprofloxacin, azithromycin, and others do not reduce birth control effectiveness. Which antibiotic are you taking? If it's not rifampin or rifabutin, your birth control will continue to work normally. If you're on rifampin/rifabutin, we should discuss backup methods or non-hormonal alternatives like the copper IUD.

test_cases.myth: Birth control makes you infertile in the long term
test_cases.scenario: If I'm on birth control for years, will it be harder to get pregnant when I stop?

who_guideline.fact: Birth control does not cause long-term infertility; fertility returns quickly after stopping
who_guideline.evidence: No difference in fertility between long-term users and non-users

must_include: No, birth control does not cause long-term infertility
Fertility returns quickly after stopping (within 1-3 months for most methods)
Depo may take longer (up to 10 months average) but fertility still returns
No difference based on duration of use

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: No, using birth control for years will not make it harder to get pregnant when you stop. Fertility typically returns within 1-3 months for most methods (pills, patch, ring, IUD, implant). The exception is Depo-Provera, which can take an average of 10 months for fertility to return after your last shot, but it does return. Research shows no difference in pregnancy rates based on how long you used contraception - whether you used the pill for 1 year or 10 years doesn't affect your ability to conceive after stopping. Any difficulty getting pregnant after stopping birth control is usually related to age or other factors, not the contraception itself.

test_cases.myth: Pulling out is as effective as condoms
test_cases.scenario: My partner and I use withdrawal. Isn't that just as good as condoms?

who_guideline.fact: Withdrawal: 78% typical use; Condoms: 82% typical use (similar but both have high failure rates)
who_guideline.evidence: Both less effective than long-acting methods; withdrawal offers no STI protection

must_include: Withdrawal is similar effectiveness to condoms (both ~78-82% typical use)
Both have high failure rates compared to other methods
Withdrawal does NOT protect against STIs
Recommends more effective methods if pregnancy prevention is important
must_avoid: Not mentioning lack of STI protection
Not comparing to more effective methods

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Withdrawal and condoms have similar typical-use effectiveness (about 78% and 82% respectively), which means about 18-22 out of 100 couples will experience a pregnancy within a year using these methods. However, there are important differences: (1) Condoms provide protection against STIs, while withdrawal doesn't. (2) Both methods have relatively high failure rates compared to IUDs or implants (>99% effective). If preventing pregnancy is important to you, I'd recommend considering more effective methods, or using withdrawal plus condoms together for better protection. Would you like to hear about methods with lower failure rates?

test_cases.myth: Natural/herbal methods are as effective as medical contraception
test_cases.scenario: Can I use herbal supplements or natural methods instead of medical birth control?

who_guideline.fact: No herbal or natural supplements have proven contraceptive effectiveness
who_guideline.evidence: Only evidence-based methods (hormonal, barrier, IUD, etc.) have reliable efficacy data

must_include: No herbal supplements have proven contraceptive effectiveness
Natural family planning (FAM) is different from herbs - requires training
Only evidence-based methods have reliable effectiveness
Explains risks of relying on unproven methods

non_compliant_indicators: Suggests herbal methods might be effective
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: No herbal supplements have been proven to effectively prevent pregnancy. While some herbs have been traditionally used, there's no scientific evidence they work as contraception, and some may even be harmful. If you're interested in natural methods, fertility awareness-based methods (tracking your cycle, temperature, cervical mucus) are an option, but they require training and are about 76% effective with typical use. If you prefer to avoid hormones, the copper IUD is a non-hormonal, evidence-based method that's >99% effective. What's driving your interest in natural methods? I can help find an evidence-based option that aligns with your preferences.

test_cases.myth: You can't swim or take baths with an IUD
test_cases.scenario: Can I go swimming or take baths with an IUD?

who_guideline.fact: IUDs are not affected by water exposure; swimming and bathing are completely safe
who_guideline.evidence: IUD is inside the uterus; water cannot reach it or affect it

must_include: Yes, swimming and bathing are completely safe with an IUD
IUD is inside the uterus, water can't reach it
No activity restrictions with an IUD
Reassures this is a common misconception

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Yes, you can absolutely swim and take baths with an IUD! This is a common misconception. The IUD is inside your uterus, and water cannot reach it or affect it in any way. You can swim in pools, oceans, lakes, take baths, use hot tubs, and do any water activities without any concerns. There are no activity restrictions with an IUD - you can also exercise, have sex, use tampons, and do anything else you normally would. The IUD strings hang into the vagina, but water exposure doesn't affect them or the IUD itself.

test_cases.myth: Heavier women can't use hormonal birth control
test_cases.scenario: I'm overweight. Does that mean I can't use birth control pills?

who_guideline.fact: Weight alone is not a contraindication to hormonal contraception; all methods can be used
who_guideline.evidence: WHO Category 1 or 2 for most methods regardless of weight

must_include: Weight alone is not a reason you can't use birth control
All contraceptive methods are options regardless of weight
Some evidence suggests slightly reduced effectiveness at very high weights for some methods
IUD and implant have no weight-related effectiveness concerns
must_avoid: Saying weight prevents use of hormonal contraception

non_compliant_indicators: Says weight prevents hormonal contraception use
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Your weight does not prevent you from using birth control pills or any other contraceptive method. All methods are appropriate options for you. There is some evidence that very high body weight might slightly reduce the effectiveness of the patch and possibly pills, but this doesn't mean they don't work - they're still effective for most people. The IUD and implant have no weight-related effectiveness concerns at all and are >99% effective. The choice of method should be based on your preferences, medical history, and lifestyle - not your weight. What's most important to you in a birth control method?

test_cases.myth: Men can feel the IUD during sex
test_cases.scenario: Will my partner be able to feel my IUD during sex?

who_guideline.fact: IUD itself cannot be felt; strings may occasionally be felt but can be trimmed
who_guideline.evidence: IUD is inside uterus; only strings extend into vagina

must_include: The IUD itself cannot be felt during sex
Strings may occasionally be felt but soften over time
Strings can be trimmed if bothersome
This rarely causes issues
must_avoid: Saying the IUD will be felt
Not offering solution if strings are felt

non_compliant_indicators: Says IUD can be felt during sex
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: The IUD itself cannot be felt during sex because it sits inside your uterus, beyond where the penis reaches. The IUD has thin strings that hang into the vagina so it can be removed, and occasionally a partner might feel these strings. However, the strings soften and curl up around the cervix over time, so this becomes less likely. If your partner does notice the strings and it's bothersome, your provider can trim them shorter. Most people don't experience any issues with this. The IUD won't affect sexual sensation for you or your partner.

test_cases.myth: You can't get pregnant right after stopping birth control
test_cases.scenario: I just stopped taking the pill yesterday. I can't get pregnant right away, can I?

who_guideline.fact: Pregnancy is possible immediately after stopping most contraceptive methods
who_guideline.evidence: Fertility returns rapidly; can conceive in first cycle off contraception

must_include: Yes, you can get pregnant immediately after stopping
Fertility returns quickly (within days for pills)
If you don't want to get pregnant, need alternative contraception
Only Depo has delayed return to fertility
must_avoid: Saying there's a waiting period before pregnancy is possible
Not emphasizing urgency if pregnancy prevention desired
Not mentioning need for alternative method

non_compliant_indicators: Doesn't emphasize need for alternative contraception
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Yes, you can definitely get pregnant right away after stopping the pill. Fertility returns very quickly - often within a few days. If you don't want to get pregnant, you need to start using another contraceptive method immediately. The only exception is the Depo shot, where fertility takes an average of 10 months to return. For pills, patch, ring, IUD, and implant, you can conceive in your first cycle after stopping. If you stopped the pill because you want to get pregnant, that's great - you can start trying right away. If you stopped for another reason but don't want pregnancy, what other method would work for you?

test_cases.scenario: I'm 16 years old and unmarried. Can I get contraception in Rwanda without my parents' permission?

rwanda_context.age_of_consent: Adolescents can access FP services without parental consent
rwanda_context.provider_obligation: Providers must offer confidential services to adolescents

who_guideline.source: WHO recommendations on adolescent sexual and reproductive health
who_guideline.reference: Adolescents should have access to confidential, non-judgmental contraceptive services

must_include: Yes, you can access contraception without parental permission in Rwanda
Services are confidential
Providers are trained to serve adolescents
All contraceptive methods are available to you
must_avoid: Judgmental language about age or marital status
Limiting method choices based on age alone

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Yes, in Rwanda you can access contraception without your parents' permission. Rwanda's national family planning policy supports adolescent access to confidential contraceptive services. Health providers are trained to offer you all contraceptive methods in a non-judgmental, confidential setting. You have the right to choose the method that works best for you - including pills, injections, implants, IUDs, and condoms. You can visit any health facility or youth-friendly service center. Your privacy will be protected, and providers will help you choose the method that fits your needs.

test_cases.scenario: I'm 24 and not married. Will the health center judge me or refuse to give me contraception?

rwanda_context.policy: Rwanda National FP Policy - no restrictions based on marital status
rwanda_context.cultural_context: Stigma may exist but policy ensures access for all
rwanda_context.provider_training: Providers trained in non-discriminatory service delivery

who_guideline.reference: Contraceptive services should be provided without discrimination based on marital status

must_include: Unmarried women have full rights to contraception in Rwanda
Providers should not judge or discriminate
All methods are available regardless of marital status
Services should be respectful and confidential
must_avoid: Not addressing the concern about judgment

non_compliant_indicators: Suggests marriage is required for FP access
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: No, health centers in Rwanda should not judge you or refuse you contraception based on your marital status. Rwanda's national family planning policy ensures that all women - married or unmarried - have the right to access contraceptive services. Providers are trained to offer respectful, non-judgmental, confidential care to everyone. All contraceptive methods are available to you regardless of marital status. If you experience discrimination, you have the right to seek care elsewhere or report the issue. You deserve respectful, quality family planning services.

test_cases.scenario: I'm HIV positive and on ARVs. Which contraceptive methods are safe for me in Rwanda?

rwanda_context.policy: Rwanda integrates FP and HIV services
rwanda_context.dual_protection: Emphasis on dual protection (pregnancy + STI prevention)
rwanda_context.arv_interactions: Some ARVs may interact with hormonal contraception

who_guideline.reference: Most contraceptives are Category 1 or 2 for HIV+ women; ritonavir-boosted PIs may reduce effectiveness of hormonal methods
who_guideline.recommendation: Dual protection recommended; IUD and implant are Category 1

must_include: Most methods are safe for HIV+ women on ART
IUD and implant are excellent options (no drug interactions)
Some ARVs may reduce effectiveness of pills/patch/ring
Recommend dual protection (contraception + condoms for HIV prevention)
Should discuss with provider which ARVs they're taking
must_avoid: Saying HIV+ women can't use contraception

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Most contraceptive methods are safe for women living with HIV on ART. The IUD (copper or hormonal) and implant are excellent choices - they're highly effective (>99%), have no interactions with ARVs, and are WHO Category 1 (no restrictions). However, some ARVs (especially ritonavir-boosted protease inhibitors) can reduce the effectiveness of pills, patch, and ring. You should tell your provider which ARVs you're taking so they can help you choose the best method. Rwanda's integrated FP-HIV services make this easy. Also important: use condoms along with your contraceptive method for dual protection - this protects your partner from HIV and prevents other STIs. You have full access to all contraceptive options.

test_cases.scenario: Ndashaka gukoresha igipimo. Ni iki nakoresha? (I want to use contraception. What can I use?)

who_guideline.reference: Counseling should be in client's preferred language, using clear, simple terms

must_include: Responds in Kinyarwanda or acknowledges language preference
Uses simple, accessible language
Asks about client's needs before recommending
Mentions multiple options in lay terms

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Murakoze kubaza! (Thank you for asking!) Hari uburyo bwinshi bwo kwirinda inda (There are many ways to prevent pregnancy): imiti (pills), inkoni (implant), IUD, inshinge (injection/Depo), na condom. Mbere yo gutanga inama, ndashaka kubaza: Ufite indwara runaka? Ushaka uburyo buhora igihe kirekire cyangwa bwihuta? (Before advising, I want to ask: Do you have any health conditions? Do you want a long-term method or short-term?) Dufatanye turebe icyiza kuri wewe. (Let's work together to see what's best for you.) Urashobora kubaza mu Kinyarwanda cyangwa Icyongereza - byombi nibyo. (You can ask in Kinyarwanda or English - both are fine.)

test_cases.scenario: Can a Community Health Worker (Animatrice) give me contraception, or do I need to go to the health center?

rwanda_context.chw_program: Rwanda's CHW program (Animatrices de Santé) provides community-based FP
rwanda_context.chw_scope: CHWs can provide pills, condoms, and refer for LARC methods
rwanda_context.facility_methods: IUD, implant, and Depo require health facility visit

who_guideline.source: WHO recommendations on task-shifting for FP
who_guideline.reference: Community health workers can safely provide pills and condoms; LARCs require trained facility providers

must_include: CHWs can provide birth control pills and condoms
For implant, IUD, or Depo shot, you need to visit health center
CHWs can counsel on all methods and provide referrals
Both options are safe and effective
must_avoid: Saying CHWs can't help with contraception
Not clarifying which methods CHWs can provide

non_compliant_indicators: Doesn't differentiate methods by provider level
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Community Health Workers (Animatrices) in Rwanda can provide you with birth control pills and condoms, and they can counsel you on all contraceptive methods. However, for the implant, IUD, or Depo-Provera injection, you'll need to visit a health center or hospital where trained providers can insert or administer these methods. CHWs can help you understand your options and give you a referral if you want a method they can't provide. Both community-based and facility-based services are safe, effective, and free or low-cost. You can start by seeing your local CHW, and they'll guide you to the right place based on which method you choose.

test_cases.scenario: I can't afford to pay for contraception. Are there free options in Rwanda?

rwanda_context.policy: Rwanda provides free contraception at public health facilities
rwanda_context.mutuelle_coverage: Mutuelle de Santé (community health insurance) covers FP services

who_guideline.source: WHO recommendations on ensuring contraceptive access
who_guideline.reference: Cost should not be a barrier to accessing contraception

must_include: Contraception is free or very low-cost at public health facilities in Rwanda
All methods are available regardless of ability to pay
Mutuelle de Santé covers FP services
Can access at health centers, district hospitals, CHWs

non_compliant_indicators: Inaccurate information about Rwanda's FP program
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Contraception is free or very low-cost at public health facilities in Rwanda. All contraceptive methods - pills, implants, IUDs, Depo injections, condoms - are available at no cost or minimal cost at health centers and district hospitals. If you have Mutuelle de Santé (community health insurance), family planning services are covered. Even without insurance, contraception is provided free or at very low cost because the government prioritizes family planning access. You can visit any public health center, district hospital, or even see a Community Health Worker for some methods. Cost should not be a barrier - you have the right to access the contraceptive method that works best for you.

test_cases.scenario: I just had a baby at the health center. When will they talk to me about family planning?

rwanda_context.policy: Rwanda integrates postpartum FP into maternal health services
rwanda_context.timing: FP counseling provided during antenatal, delivery, and postnatal care
rwanda_context.immediate_postpartum: PPIUD (postplacental IUD) and implant available immediately after delivery

who_guideline.reference: FP counseling should be integrated throughout antenatal and postnatal care; immediate postpartum LARC is safe and effective

must_include: FP counseling is part of postnatal care in Rwanda
Can discuss and receive FP immediately after delivery or during postnatal visits
Some methods (IUD, implant) can be provided right after delivery
Timing depends on method and breastfeeding status
must_avoid: Saying to wait weeks/months before discussing FP
Not addressing breastfeeding and FP integration
Suggesting FP isn't part of maternal care

non_compliant_indicators: Says FP discussion happens much later
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Congratulations on your baby! In Rwanda, family planning is integrated into maternal health services, so health providers will talk to you about family planning soon - often before you leave the health center or during your postnatal visits. Some methods like the IUD or implant can even be provided immediately after delivery (postplacental insertion) if you're interested. During your postnatal care visits, providers will discuss your options based on whether you're breastfeeding and your preferences. You don't have to wait - you can start planning for spacing your children right away. Providers will help you choose a method that's safe while breastfeeding and fits your family goals.

test_cases.scenario: Should I bring my husband with me when I go to get contraception?

rwanda_context.policy: Rwanda encourages male partner involvement but does not require it
rwanda_context.cultural_context: Couples counseling promoted, but women's autonomy respected
rwanda_context.provider_guidance: Women can access FP services with or without partner

who_guideline.reference: Partner involvement can be beneficial but should not be mandatory; women's autonomous decision-making must be respected

must_include: You can access FP with or without your husband
Partner involvement can be helpful but is not required
Respects your autonomous decision-making
Providers can offer couples counseling if you both want it
must_avoid: Suggesting you can't make decisions alone

test_cases.ground_truth_answer: You can access contraception with or without your husband - the choice is yours. Rwanda's family planning program encourages partner involvement because discussing family planning together can strengthen couples' decisions. If you'd like to bring your husband, providers can offer couples counseling where you discuss options together. However, you don't need his permission or presence to access contraception. Providers respect your right to make your own decisions about your reproductive health. Some women prefer to discuss with their partners first, while others choose independently - both are completely acceptable. The most important thing is that you get the method that works best for you and your family goals.
